natural problem: What is the least possible value of the sum $|x - 1| + |x - 1.5| + |x - 2|$?
natural solution: We tackle this with some careful casework. Case 1: $x\ge 2$.

We then have $|x-1| + |x-1.5| + |x-2| = (x-1) + (x-1.5) + (x-2) = 3x - 4.5$. Since the smallest value of $x$ in this case is $2$, the smallest possible value of the sum in this case is $3(2) - 4.5 = 1.5$.

We then have  \begin{align} |x-1| + |x-1.5| + |x-2| & = (x-1) + (x-1.5) + (-(x-2)) \\ & = 2x - 2.5 -x+2 \\ & = x -0.5. \end{align} Since the smallest possible value of $x$ in this case is $1.5$, the smallest possible value of the sum in this case is $1.5-0.5 = 1$.

We then have  \begin{align} |x-1| + |x-1.5| + |x-2| & = (x-1) - (x-1.5) - (x-2) \\ & = x-1 -x + 1.5-x+2 \\ & = -x +2.5. \end{align} Since $x$ is less than 1.5, the sum in this case is greater than $-1.5+2.5 = 1$.

We then have  \begin{align} |x-1| + |x-1.5| + |x-2| & = -(x-1) - (x-1.5) - (x-2) \\ & = -3x + 4.5. \end{align} Since $x$ is less than 1, the sum in this case is greater than $-3(1) + 4.5 = 1.5$. Reviewing these cases, we see that the least possible sum is $\boxed{1}$.
As an extra challenge, see if you can find a quick solution to this problem by thinking about the graph of $y = | x-1| + |x-1.5| + |x-2|$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
shows  "abs(x - 1) + abs(x - 1.5) + abs(x - 2) >= 1"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the least possible value of the sum $|x - 1| + |x - 1.5| + |x - 2|$? The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 We tackle this with some careful casework. Case 1: $x\ge 2$.
 We then have $|x-1| + |x-1.5| + |x-2| = (x-1) + (x-1.5) + (x-2) = 3x - 4.5$. Since the smallest value of $x$ in this case is $2$, the smallest possible value of the sum in this case is $3(2) - 4.5 = 1.5$.
 Case 2: $1.5\le x < 2$.
 We then have  \begin{align} |x-1| + |x-1.5| + |x-2| & = (x-1) + (x-1.5) + (-(x-2)) \\ & = 2x - 2.5 -x+2 \\ & = x -0.5. \end{align} Since the smallest possible value of $x$ in this case is $1.5$, the smallest possible value of the sum in this case is $1.5-0.5 = 1$.
 Case 3: $1 \le x < 1.5$.
 We then have  \begin{align} |x-1| + |x-1.5| + |x-2| & = (x-1) - (x-1.5) - (x-2) \\ & = x-1 -x + 1.5-x+2 \\ & = -x +2.5. \end{align} Since $x$ is less than 1.5, the sum in this case is greater than $-1.5+2.5 = 1$.
 Case 4: $x < 1$.
 We then have  \begin{align} |x-1| + |x-1.5| + |x-2| & = -(x-1) - (x-1.5) - (x-2) \\ & = -3x + 4.5. \end{align} Since $x$ is less than 1, the sum in this case is greater than $-3(1) + 4.5 = 1.5$. Reviewing these cases, we see that the least possible sum is $\boxed{1}$.
 As an extra challenge, see if you can find a quick solution to this problem by thinking about the graph of $y = | x-1| + |x-1.5| + |x-2|$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
shows  "abs(x - 1) + abs(x - 1.5) + abs(x - 2) >= 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Show that the sum of the absolute differences between $x$ and 1, 1.5, and 2 is always greater than or equal to 1: $|x - 1| + |x - 1.5| + |x - 2| \geq 1$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
shows  "(LEAST s. \<exists> x. abs(x - 1) + abs(x - 3/2) + abs(x - 2) = s) = 1"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the least possible value of the sum $|x - 1| + |x - 1.5| + |x - 2|$? The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 We tackle this with some careful casework. Case 1: $x\ge 2$.
 We then have $|x-1| + |x-1.5| + |x-2| = (x-1) + (x-1.5) + (x-2) = 3x - 4.5$. Since the smallest value of $x$ in this case is $2$, the smallest possible value of the sum in this case is $3(2) - 4.5 = 1.5$.
 Case 2: $1.5\le x < 2$.
 We then have  \begin{align} |x-1| + |x-1.5| + |x-2| & = (x-1) + (x-1.5) + (-(x-2)) \\ & = 2x - 2.5 -x+2 \\ & = x -0.5. \end{align} Since the smallest possible value of $x$ in this case is $1.5$, the smallest possible value of the sum in this case is $1.5-0.5 = 1$.
 Case 3: $1 \le x < 1.5$.
 We then have  \begin{align} |x-1| + |x-1.5| + |x-2| & = (x-1) - (x-1.5) - (x-2) \\ & = x-1 -x + 1.5-x+2 \\ & = -x +2.5. \end{align} Since $x$ is less than 1.5, the sum in this case is greater than $-1.5+2.5 = 1$.
 Case 4: $x < 1$.
 We then have  \begin{align} |x-1| + |x-1.5| + |x-2| & = -(x-1) - (x-1.5) - (x-2) \\ & = -3x + 4.5. \end{align} Since $x$ is less than 1, the sum in this case is greater than $-3(1) + 4.5 = 1.5$. Reviewing these cases, we see that the least possible sum is $\boxed{1}$.
 As an extra challenge, see if you can find a quick solution to this problem by thinking about the graph of $y = | x-1| + |x-1.5| + |x-2|$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
shows  "(LEAST s. \<exists> x. abs(x - 1) + abs(x - 3/2) + abs(x - 2) = s) = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the smallest possible value of the sum of the absolute differences between a real number $x$ and the numbers $1, \frac{3}{2},$ and $2$. The final answer is $1$.

shows  "1 = (LEAST a. \<exists>x. a = abs (x - 1) + abs (x - 1.5) + abs (x - 2))"

 Case 4: $x < 1$.
 We then have  \begin{align} |x-1| + |x-1.5| + |x-2| & = -(x-1) - (x-1.5) - (x-2) \\ & = -3x + 4.5. \end{align} Since $x$ is less than 1, the sum in this case is greater than $-3(1) + 4.5 = 1.5$. Reviewing these cases, we see that the least possible sum is $\boxed{1}$.
 As an extra challenge, see if you can find a quick solution to this problem by thinking about the graph of $y = | x-1| + |x-1.5| + |x-2|$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
shows  "1 = (LEAST a. \<exists>x. a = abs (x - 1) + abs (x - 1.5) + abs (x - 2))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the smallest value of the expression $|x-1| + |x-1.5| + |x-2|$ for any real number $x$. The final answer is $1$.

fixes x :: real
shows  "1 = (INFIMUM a. \<exists> x. a = abs (x - 1) + abs (x - 3 / 2) + abs (x - 2))"

(* ### Problem

 We then have  \begin{align} |x-1| + |x-1.5| + |x-2| & = (x-1) - (x-1.5) - (x-2) \\ & = x-1 -x + 1.5-x+2 \\ & = -x +2.5. \end{align} Since $x$ is less than 1.5, the sum in this case is greater than $-1.5+2.5 = 1$.

 As an extra challenge, see if you can find a quick solution to this problem by thinking about the graph of $y = | x-1| + |x-1.5| + |x-2|$.
 *)

fixes x :: real
shows  "1 = (INFIMUM a. \<exists> x. a = abs (x - 1) + abs (x - 3 / 2) + abs (x - 2))"

theorem
fixes x :: real
shows  "Min {abs (x - 1) + abs (x - 1.5) + abs (x - 2)} = 1"

(* ### Problem
 What is the least possible value of the sum $|x - 1| + |x - 1.5| + |x - 2|$? The final Answer is 1
 ### Proof
 We tackle this with some careful casework. Case 1: $x\ge 2$.
 We then have $|x-1| + |x-1.5| + |x-2| = (x-1) + (x-1.5) + (x-2) = 3x - 4.5$. Since the smallest value of $x$ in this case is $2$, the smallest possible value of the sum in this case is $3(2) - 4.5 = 1.5$.

 We then have  \begin{align} |x-1| + |x-1.5| + |x-2| & = (x-1) - (x-1.5) - (x-2) \\ & = x-1 -x + 1.5-x+2 \\ & = -x +2.5. \end{align} Since $x$ is less than 1.5, the sum in this case is greater than $-1.5+2.5 = 1$.
 Case 4: $x < 1$.
 We then have  \begin{align} |x-1| + |x-1.5| + |x-2| & = -(x-1) - (x-1.5) - (x-2) \\ & = -3x + 4.5. \end{align} Since $x$ is less than 1, the sum in this case is greater than $-3(1) + 4.5 = 1.5$. Reviewing these cases, we see that the least possible sum is $\boxed{1}$.
 As an extra challenge, see if you can find a quick solution to this problem by thinking about the graph of $y = | x-1| + |x-1.5| + |x-2|$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
shows  "Min {abs (x - 1) + abs (x - 1.5) + abs (x - 2)} = 1"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find the minimum value of the expression $|x - 1| + |x - 1.5| + |x - 2|$. The final answer is 1.
